title: LA R users group: Getting better at R: Learning More Packages More Deeply & Hyper-parameter Tuning
description:
Talk 1:
Speaker: Daniel Jacobs (@djacobs7), Senior Director, Data Science Engineering at Age Of Learning. Website: www.dontyouremember.com

Title: Getting better at R By Learning More Packages More Deeply

Abstract:

Learning R means learning dozens of different packages and methods. CRAN has over 10,000 packages, and it's not always clear what's important to learn next. Once you decide what to learn, it's can be difficult to commit the important methods to memory so that you can use them easily over the next weeks or months. This talk walks you through strategies for deciding what to learn, and then committing them to memory with the spaced repetition algorithm. It gives an example of discovering what packages to learn via code analysis. Finally, it describes the development of the remembR package, which lets you study R directly in R.

Talk 2:
Speaker: Emil Hvitfeldt (@Emil_Hvitfeldt), Research Programmer at USC and Co-organizer of @laeRusers

Title: Hyper-parameter Tuning with Tune Package

Abstract:
Many statistical and machine learning models have parameters that can directly be inferred from the data. The newly released tune package is part of the tidymodels framework and allows you to do hyper-parameter tuning.

title: LA R users group: Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM): from Zero to Hero (with R and Python code)
description:
*** X-post from LA Data Science Meetup, RSVP here: *** https://www.meetup.com/Los-Angeles-Deep-Learning-Big-Data-Science-AI/events/268504778/

Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM): from Zero to Hero (with R and Python code)

Szilard Pafka, PhD
Chief Scientist, Epoch

This talk will get you started with gradient boosting machines (GBM), a
very popular machine learning technique providing state-of-the-art
accuracy on numerous business prediction problems. After a quick intro
to machine learning and the GBM algorithm, I will show how easy it is to
train and then use GBMs in real-life business applications using some
the most popular open source implementations (xgboost, lightgbm and
h2o). We’ll do all this in both R and Python with only a few lines of
code and this talk will be accessible for a wide audience (with limited
prior knowledge of machine learning). Finally, in the last part of the
talk I will provide plenty of references that can get you to the next
level. GBMs are a powerful technique to have in your machine learning
toolbox, because despite all the latest hype about deep learning (neural
nets) and “AI”, in fact GBMs usually outperform neural networks on
structured/tabular data most often encountered in business applications.

Bio:
Szilard studied Physics in the 90s and obtained a PhD by using statistical methods to analyze the risk of financial portfolios. He worked in finance, then more than a decade ago moved to become the Chief Scientist of a tech company in Santa Monica doing everything data (analysis, modeling, data visualization, machine learning, data infrastructure etc). He is the founder/organizer of several meetups in the Los Angeles area (R, data science etc) and the data science community website datascience.la. He is the author of a well-known machine learning benchmark on github (1000+ stars), a frequent speaker at conferences (keynote/invited at KDD, R-finance, Crunch, eRum and contributed at useR!, PAW, EARL, H2O World, Data Science Pop-up, Dataworks Summit etc.), and he has developed and taught graduate data science and machine learning courses as a visiting professor at two universities (UCLA and CEU in Europe).

– 7:00pm talk start

You must have a confirmed ("Yes") RSVP and please arrive by 6:55pm the latest.

12181 Bluff Creek Dr #250 · Playa Vista, CA

title: R User Group Eindhoven: Introduction to Statistics with R - Session 2 of 3
description:
This is 2nd session of 3 sessions, where we will continue focus on basic statistical concepts.

These concepts will be linked to practical examples and exercises in R. Please bring laptops if you want to have some hand-on practice.

We will also discuss 1-2 data-sets from participants to help deciding the effective approaches for analysis.

title: R User Group Eindhoven: Introduction to Statistics with R - Session 3 of 3
description:
In this session, we will develop concepts of distributions and confidence interval.

For distributions, we will especially focus on normal distributions which are also known as Guassian distributions.

We will then develop notion of confidence interval (e.g. based on observed data, how can we say that there is 95% chance that a measurement will lie between a certain interval of values)

This session is planned longer (3 hours) to have enough time to develop those concepts.

We will also plan some exercises to allow the participants to develop their understanding further. (So please bring laptops).

title: Colchester R Meetup: 2020 intro to and best of R!
description:
Welcome to 2020!

We are going to kick off the New Year with a triple header of great talks. These sessions have been designed to be a gentle but informative introduction to those who are excited to learn about the R programming language.

Session 1: "Learning and using R as a beginner" - Leyla Yaltiligil, Department of Mathematics, University of Essex

This talk will be about my journey from pure mathematics into the foray of programming and using software within my degree, ‘recreationally’ and also learning new programming languages to practice for roles that interest me. I am a final year Undergraduate Maths student and I’m fairly new to programming but I have really enjoyed my optimisation and data analysis modules and would like to explore R more.

Session 2: "Making the switch: One psychologist's journey from SPSS/Excel to R with 'basic stuff' along the way" - Dr. Vanessa Loaiza, Department of Psychology, University of Essex

Session 3: "Intro to GLRMs" - Bob Komara, MSX International & Alasdair Clarke, Department of Psychology, University of Essex

Snacks and beverages provided courtesy of IADS: https://www.essex.ac.uk/centres-and-institutes/institute-for-analytics-and-data-science

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Book club - Session 5 - R for Data Science
description:
We are looking to start a book club to improve our R skills. It will be headed up by Xi Chen. The idea is to motivate us to read books and discussing them together. This will help all of us to develop our skills.

The format will be that the leader will prepare a short summary of the material and present it to the group. We will then discuss the material and do some exercises.

* Book

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Power BI and March Madness
description:
# Introduction

Power BI is a business analytics solution that lets you visualize data, share insights, or embed them in an app or website. It allows easy access to connect to hundreds of data sources, create dashboards and reports. Power BI, can run R scripts and create data models and visualizations. Suresh will give a demo on how you can use your R stills to interact with Power BI.

March Madness, the NCAA basketball tournament that takes us by storm every March is right around the corner. ncaahoopR is an R package for working with NCAA Basketball Play-by-Play Data. It scrapes play-by-play data and returns it to the user in a tidy format and allows the user to explore the data with assist networks and in-game win-probability charts.

Come early, network and enjoy the food.

# Schedule

6:30 - 6:50 Networking
6:50 - 7:00 Welcome & general announcement
7:00 - 7:30 Using R in Power BI
7:30 - 8:00 Basketball: Let's Explore March Madness with ncaahoopR
8:00 - 8:30 Networking and Clean-up

# Talk 1

## Title: Using R in Power BI
## Speaker: Suresh Datla
## Abstract

Power BI is a business analytics solution that lets you visualize data, share insights, or embed them in an app or website. It allows easy access to connect to hundreds of data sources, create dashboards and reports. Power BI, can run R scripts and create data models and visualizations. Suresh will give a demo on how you can use your R stills to interact with Power BI.

# Talk 2

## Title: Basketball: Let's Explore March Madness with ncaahoopR
## Speaker: Luke Morris
## Abstract

March Madness is right around the corner. Whether your interest in college basketball lasts for one month or all year round, the ncaahoopR package can catch you up on the teams or games you care about, and maybe even keep you alive in that office pool a while longer.

title: The Chicago R User Group (CRUG): Double Feature: Many Ways to Lasso & Object Oriented Programming in R
description:
We have another exciting meetup, featuring Jared Lander, author of author of "R for Everyone" as well as Anthony Shook, Lead Data Scientist at Jellyvision Labs, inc.

Doors open at 5:30 talks begin at 6 pm. Vittles will be served, sponsored by IBM!

Jared Lander: Many ways to Lasso
Anthony Shook, Ph.D: Object-Oriented Programming in R

Anthony started using R more than 10 years ago because he hated Excel, and has never looked back! A former Northwestern Professor, Anthony will teach us about S3, S4, and R6 object oriented systems in R. https://www.jellyvision.com/ https://www.linkedin.com/in/ajshook/

Jared P. Lander is Chief Data Scientist of Lander Analytics, the Organizer of the New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup and the New York, Washington DC and Dublin R Conferences and an Adjunct Professor at Columbia Business School. He is the author of R for Everyone, a book about R Programming geared toward Data Scientists and Non-Statisticians alike. His writings on statistics can be found at jaredlander.com.
The Lasso remains an excellent statistical learning technique for modeling data sets containing many variables/features. While glmnet remains the classic package for applying the approach using R, Jared will show us how one can Lasso with additional R packages interfacing Keras, lars, Stan, xgboost, spark, and quadratic programming.

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group
description:
Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: St. Petersburg R User Group: SPbR #16
description:
Привет! Сезон 2020 мы открываем двумя докладами: про временные ряды и про кредитный скоринг, и необычной для нас активностью: тематическими обсуждениями aka круглые столы, в этот раз — про воспроизводимость кода и про карьеру с R.

Расписание:

19:00 Организаторы расскажут про планы на сегодня

19:10 Андрей Головин, ведущий инженер в компании Electrolux: детектирование события с помощью классификации временных рядов
"Расскажу про задачу детектирования появления события для данных в виде временных рядов с использованием трех подходов: классические алгоритмы классификации, DL и классификация на основе формы сигнала."

19:30 Вопросы Андрею, перерыв

19:45 Николай Никитин, инженер Национального центра когнитивных разработок Университета ИТМО: как эффективно разработать современную модель кредитного скоринга на R
"Я расскажу, с какими сложностями столкнулась наша команда при разработке модели кредитного скоринга и какие подходы были использованы для ее эффективного решения с помощью R."

20:15 Вопросы Николаю, перерыв

20:20 Круглые столы по темам:
- Воспроизводимость кода/исследования: нужна ли вообще? Когда и как? Модератор — Василий Каминский
- Карьера: что делать, если знаешь R? Модератор — Владимир Волохонский
И ещё с 20:00 у вас появится возможность пообщаться с командой разработчиков R плагина из JetBrains – узнать о новом плагине, посмотреть демо или просто задать вопросы.

Будет запись и трансляция.

*****
Самая актуальная информация, материалы и записи докладов в группе https://vk.com/spbrug

Обратите внимание: в этот раз мы снова встречаемся в новом офисе JetBrains у метро Беговая. Если вы приехали на своей машине, то после перекрёстка Яхтенной улицы и Приморского проспекта вам стоит повернуть налево, под шлагбаум. Охрана здания пропустит вас на парковку офиса, если вы скажете, что приехали на митап. Если вы приехали на машине каршеринга, лучше оставьте её на парковке ТЦ Питерлэнд. Если вы приехали на общественном транспорте или пешком, то просто проходите мимо шлагбаума, поднимайтесь по большой центральной лестнице и входите в центральные двери. Там вас будут ждать!

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): February Boston useR Group Event
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Two Speakers for February!

#1
Sync up your interactive dashboards with crosstalk AND rstudio::conf 2020 recap!

Abstract:
You can build amazing interactive dashboards in R Markdown using the flexdashboard package and HTML widgets. Sometimes, though, you want all your interactive components to synchronize their outputs to user inputs instead of all acting independently. That’s exactly what the crosstalk package does. Carl Howe, RStudio’s Director of Education, will show attendees how to use the crosstalk package on RStudio Cloud, and each of you can try it out for yourselves. When Carl demonstrated this package during his R Markdown and Interactive Dashboards workshop, many of the attendees said this one package was worth the entire price of the workshop; we think you’ll find it worth knowing about.

Carl and Rachael Dempsey will also recap the highlights of rstudio::conf 2020 held in San Francisco on January 27-30, 2020, and they’ll provide links to the conference content so that you can download many of the materials yourselves.

#2
Building Simple Equity Momentum Strategy with R

Abstract:
Al Yazdani, PhD, is the Machine Learning and Quantitative Research Manager at State Street Associates in Cambridge, MA. He leads a research group of data scientists tasked with the novel applications of data-driven methods in quantitative finance, particularly the applications of machine learning methods in risk and return strategies for FX and Equities portfolios. In his presentation, Al will demonstrate how to use R capabilities to develop simple yet effective Equities Momentum Investment strategies.

Location:
WeWork One Beacon Street

WeWork is a community of creators. We transform buildings into collaborative workspaces. Our mission is to help companies grow by providing them with not just beautiful space but benefits, amenities, and community they need to focus on their business, all on very flexible terms. We currently have over 200,000 Members working out of our communities worldwide, and over 6,000 members here in Boston.

Pizza will be provided by RStudio

title: Boston R/Bioconductor for Genomics: Bioconductor Docker & Containers with Nitesh Turaga
description:
Bioconductor Docker & Containers (Reschedule from Sept)

Bioconductor provides a range of options that allow users and developers to perform their analysis using containers, taking away the burden of installing dependencies and system requirements. Containers allow software to be used in a reproducible, reliable and isolated fashion.

Bioconductor also produce containers that replicate their build machines to allow developers contributing to the project to test their changes more aggressively before being put in production. These containers will provide the base infrastructure for cloud/web platforms in the near future. This talk will highlight how to use these containers effectively through docker on your local machine and demo their usage in the cloud.

For this meetup

Slides: https://bit.ly/bioc-docker-2020
Demo: https://github.com/nturaga/r-bioconductor-meetup

Nitesh Turaga
Bioconductor Core Team, Roswell Park
https://www.bioconductor.org/about/core-team/
I'm a Senior Programmer in the Core team at the Bioconductor Project. I've been building open-source bioinformatics software since 2013, first at the Galaxy Project at Johns Hopkins and now at the Bioconductor Project. I'm passionate about programming, R, and data

https://github.com/nturaga

title: CopenhagenR - useR Group: celebRation 2020
description:
CelebRation 2020
R conference in Copenhagen, Denmark, February[masked] celebrating the 20th anniversary of R version v1.0.0

The year 2020 marks the 20th anniversary of the release of R version 1.0.0!

To celebrate this, we are inviting the community of R users and developers for a two-day celebRation 28-29th February 2020. We kick off on 28th February with hands-on workshops on two hot topics, namely data visualization using the ggplot2 package and making fast extensions of R using the rcpp package. The day of the anniversary – February 29 – presents a line-up of speakers who cover the past, the present, and the future of the R programming language.

To get more information and register go to http://www.celebration2020.org/

YOU CANNOT SIGN UP THROUGH MEETUP!

title: Grupo de Usuarios de R de Madrid: 64 - Reunión Grupo de R: Jueves 13 de febrero de 2020
group: Grupo de Usuarios de R de Madrid
description:
Comenzamos el año (con un poco de retraso) con una nueva reunión del Grupo con esta agenda:

+ Pedro Concejero:
* "Persuasión de masas por métodos psicográficos ... y algún escándalo en Facebook".
El comúnmente conocido como "escándalo Cambridge Analytica" (elección de Donald Trump, Brexit, etc.) puede parecer simplemente uno (más) de los casos de filtrado de datos de Facebook, pero en realidad se trata de una (más) de las aplicaciones de una tecnología conocida como microtargetting, en este caso basado en las inferencias de la personalidad a partir de nuestros datos de navegación.

¿Hasta qué punto es potente esta tecnología para su aplicación masiva -o "massive persuasion"? Uno de los creadores de la base científica de estas técnicas, Michal Kosinski, explica en sus últimos artículos hasta qué punto sí lo es, y también por qué en su opinión estas aplicaciones pueden ser un gran reto para la privacidad y para la ética en general en el uso de herramientas Big Data.

En la charla revisaremos y reproduciremos los resultados ofrecidos por el Dr. Kosinski en sus investigaciones, a partir de su propio código y datos.

+ José Manuel Ropero
* ”Modelización de un Customer Journey en Banca con R/Keras”.
El equipo de Analytics de Rural Servicios Informáticos presenta un caso de uso real donde, mediante el uso de técnicas basadas en redes neuronales, se aborda un problema novedoso en el sector bancario.

title: Winnipeg R User Group: Winnipeg R User Group - Meeting #11
description:
Winnipeg R User Group Meeting #11 - Connecting RStudio with GitHub

GitHub is a version control system that can be seamlessly integrated into the Data Science workflow to support reproducible science.

Data scientists, researchers and statisticians have been using GitHub more and more as data analytics teams grow in size with multiple analysts collaborating on larger projects.

As Jenny Bryan has stated:

“Data analysis, statistical research, and teaching statistics have at least one thing in common: these activities all produce many files ! .....
….. Most of these files evolve over the course of a project and often need to be shared with others, for reading or edits, as a project unfolds.
Without explicit and structured file management, project organization can easily descend into chaos, taking time away from the primary work and reducing the quality of the final product.
This unhappy result can be avoided by re-purposing tools and workflows from the software development world, namely, distributed version control.”

GitHub nicely compliments RStudio Projects by creating an online repository for your local folders.

In this meeting, Marcello Nesca will lead a workshop to achieve the following:

* Making a GitHub profile
* Connecting RStudio with GitHub
* Creating repositories
* Set up a R project with multiple users
* Following people

Please bring a laptop computer if you wish to do the hands-on exercises at this meeting.

____________________________________________

The Winnipeg R User Group is sponsored by The R Consortium

https://www.r-consortium.org

title: Winnipeg R User Group: Winnipeg R User Group - Meeting #12
description:
Winnipeg R User Group Meeting #12 - Reprex and Datapasta

One day you will need to ask for help on questions regarding coding, research design, or statistical analysis, including choosing proper machine learning models.

'reprex' and 'datapasta' will render your data so that it's friendly to ask questions over forums when you do not have the knowledge or someone immediate to help you.

'reprex', by Jenny Bryan, is part of the Tidyverse; and stands for “Reproducible Example”.

'datapasta' allows for very easy copying and pasting your data; and is used easily with 'reprex'.

These tools are excellent, especially if you have errors in your code and have no idea why they are happening, and you need to ask someone for help.

In this meeting, Marcello Nesca will demonstrate how the use of 'reprex' and 'datapasta' tools are “Best Practices” for data reproducibility.

Please bring a laptop computer if you wish to do the hands-on exercises at this meeting.

title: Saint Louis R User Group: Improving R code performance
description:
By: Ehsan Jahanpour

R was initially developed for data analysis and statistics in 1993. Since then, it has gained a lot of use from academia & industry. The user-friendly & open-source RStudio IDE made the programming language even more popular. Nowadays, there are a lot of applications, dashboards and APIs are developed in R using shiny, plotly, plumber and lot of other packages.

However, as data size getting bigger and messier, we would need to use additional techniques and packages to improve the coding and pay more attention to how R interacts with our system resources. In this meetup, I will explain different programming techniques for reading in and searching through datasets as they get bigger. Also, I will discuss on how profiling can be useful in R to find the bottlenecks and pay attention to the part of the script that matters the most.

As a meetup spoiler, I will use the “profvis” package for profiling and evaluating the performance of “read.table” vs “fread” for reading datasets and “for loops” vs “apply family” vs “foreach" package for looping over objects.

title: SheffieldR - Sheffield R Users Group: R-Shiny for Decision Making and Debugging in RStudio
description:
R-Shiny for Decision Making

A short presentation on the use of R-Shiny to aid decision makers. Two examples are open source; including a study of the social and geographic disparities in the access to and the participation in parkrun events in England. The project aimed to support parkrun’s planned expansion, by providing recommendations for 200 new event locations, maximising access for deprived communities.

http://iol-map.shef.ac.uk/

Robert Smith is a PhD Student in Public Health Economics & Decision Science, ScHARR.

Getting to know the debugger in RStudio

If you're writing moderately complicated code in R there are times when your code throws an error but you don't know why: the error occurs inside a function or loop, the error message is obtuse or unhelpful, one of the many parameter sets you're processing is causing a problem... In this talk I'll introduce the debugger in RStudio, which helps you to get inside your code and diagnose problems from within.

Tamora James is a PhD researcher in Animal and Plant Sciences with a former life as a web and software developer. She is a co-organiser of the Sheffield R Users Group and a contributor to the British Ecological Society publication ‘A Guide to Reproducible Code in Ecology and Evolution’.

title: Bay Area useR Group (R Programming Language): "Official" February 2020 BARUG Meetup
group: Bay Area useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Our February meetup will be held in conjunction with the Biotech-Pharma R User Meetup. This is our first joint meeting and I believe it will be a special event.

However, in addition to sending a positive RSVP on this page you must also register here: https://bbsw-tickets.ticketleap.com/bbswuser-r-user-meetup/

Agenda:
6:30 - Reception and Networking
7:00 - Announcements
7:10 - Tony Chang - Validating R in the Biotech-Pharma Industry
7:30 - Doug KelKhoff - Building Trust in Open Source Scientific Software: Grassroots Software Validation for R
8:05 - Dan Putler - Understanding Opioid Prescribing Behavior in England

#######
Tony Chang
Title: Validating R in the Biotech-Pharma Industry

SAS has been the gold standard system for statistical analysis and reporting in the Biotech-Pharma industry. Whereas R has been increasingly used by data science communities. Biotech-Pharma can take many advantages of R, such as data visualization to analyze and present clinical trial data for decision making and regulatory submission. However per guidance, computerized systems used in clinical research in a regulatory setting must be validated, and validating R is extremely challenging because of the nature of an open source environment. This presentation will discuss the validation requirements per regulatory guidance for both system setup and application development. In addition, we will share our experience of building validated and non-validated R distributions at BioMarin, which include 1) the infrastructure of the R platform, and 2) key components of R validation process: the package management process, and package validation framework. Our exploratory work suggests that with an appropriate system infrastructure and process setup, validating R in the Biotech-Pharma industry is achievable.

###########
Doug KelKhoff
Building Trust in Open Source Scientific Software: Grassroots Software Validation for R

Many regulated industries are at a turning point in their adoption of open source tools. To stay competitive, these companies must make use of open source tooling, which often have the first or most well adopted implementations of novel methods. Likewise, as the tooling around open source development has improved, the tools have followed, to the point that most recent graduates have roots in open source languages and prioritize publishing methods with open source implementations. This form of software development is quite new to many regulated industries, and the decades-long processes that govern software validation are being strained to accommodate the influx of community code.

I'll discuss ongoing work to build shared, cross-industry tooling for R package validation, how open source tools can be reproducibly delivered for regulators, and how these two pieces combine to provide a cross-industry mechanism to deliver reproducible results with.

############
Dan Putler
# Understanding Opioid Prescribing Behavior in England

I make use of both the R spdep and splm packages, coupled with the Alteryx analytics platform, to develop a spatial panel model to examine the drivers of prescribing behavior for opioid analgesics on the part of general practice physicians in England, relying on data from the Office of National Statistics for England and Wales, the National Health Service of England, and the commercial data provider MB-Research.

The analysis reveals that socioeconomic and demographic characteristics of an area play a major role in opioid prescription rates among physicians, which are consistent with Case and Deaton's findings of "deaths of despair" in the US. However, strong spatial dependence patterns are also at play, which indicate that there are systematic differences in physicians' willingness to prescribe opioids across England. This suggests that the traditional public health approach of providing regional physician training could be useful in lowering opioid prescription rates and related opioid overdose deaths.

Big Data in R

Big data takes many forms. Sometimes it’s large CSV files on your computer. Sometimes it’s data in an external database. Sometimes it’s data in a corporate data lake. In this talk, we will look at how to use the power of dplyr and other R packages to work with big data in various formats to arrive at meaningful insight using a familiar and consistent set of tools.

title: Melbourne Users of R Network (MelbURN): Text Analytics with StarSpace in R
description:

Text Analytics with StarSpace in R:
In this talk we will discuss how Bunnings implemented a Natural Language Processing technique called StarSpace which was developed by the Facebook AI Research team. In industry, messy data is the norm, but what about data with messy labels? We use the TagSpace algorithm (from StarSpace) to learn feature representations for short textual documents that takes advantage of an abundance of inconsistently applied labels.

Bio:

In his free time he enjoys writing Data Science articles, implementing the latest Natural Language Processing models, experimenting with Evolutionary Algorithms and participating in the occasional Kaggle competition. Outside the data space, you might find Ben jumping on a trampoline, experimenting with savoury baking or curled up with a book.

description:
Bentornati Community R-Ladies Bari

Il prossimo evento

Sei un utente Excel e hai paura di immergerti in R? sei fortunata/o! R-Ladies Bari è qui per sconfiggere quelle paure! Con questo incontro, forniremo risorse ed esempi di cui hai bisogno per iniziare a fare alcune delle cose di base che sei abituata/o a fare in Excel in R.
Il prossimo evento, che si terrà il 28 Febbraio presso IC406 (Bari) dalle 18:00 alle 20:30, si focalizzerà su lasciare a casa Excel ed iniziare ad utilizzare R .

Cosa imparerai?

Quest'evento, e il successivo (3 aprile 2020), saranno interamente dedicati a introdurre R e Rstudio. Vogliamo offrire un'opportunità a tutti i beginners di R di imparare le basi per poter poi crescere insieme nei prossimi mesi.
In questo primo evento ci occuperemo di gestione e creazione di dataset per fare analisi statistiche. Nell'evento successivo scopriremo come visualizzare i risultati e scrivere report di facile consumo attraverso R.
Negli ultimi 30 minuti faremo networking per conoscerci meglio. IC406 ha gentilmente deciso di offrire ai partecipanti snack e bibite per rendere questo momento sociale più piacevole (se avete allergie importanti, scriveteci a [masked]).

Cosa devi portare con te?

• Un laptop con installata una versione recente di R (https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/base/) e RStudio Desktop (qui trovate l’ultima versione: https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/)
• Volontà e curiosità per imparare!
• Rispetto e pazienza verso gli altri partecipanti secondo il codice di comportamento di RLadies (https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/)

Chi siamo e a chi sono rivolti i nostri eventi?

RLadies Bari è un gruppo locale che si rifà a RLadies Global (https://rladies.org/about-us/), un’organizzazione internazionale non-profit con circa[masked] membri in 46 diversi paesi del mondo. Lo scopo dell’organizzazione è di promuovere diversità ed equità di genere nella comunità di utenti di R.
Se utilizzi, o vorresti imparare ad utilizzare R, questo è il gruppo giusto! Tutti sono benvenuti gratuitamente, previa registrazione a , ed hanno la possibilità di imparare in un contesto amicale e di supporto.

title: Budapest Data & Pizza: Budapest Data & Pizza Night II. - Networks
description:
A Budapest Data & Pizza szervezői szeretettel várnak mindenkit második meetup alkalmukra, melyen ezúttal a hálózatokról lesz szó.

Napirend:
18:30 - Kapunyitás
19:00 - Előadások
20:15 - Kerekasztal beszélgetés
21:00 - Pizza
21:45 - Meetup vége

Program:

Bencsné Bokányi Eszter - Enriching urban space from digital footprints

Human interaction defines the structure and function of regions and cities. Online social media data provides researchers an unprecedented collection of digital human footprints that opens new possibilities to study these connections at a microscopic level. Recently, many studies tried to characterize different interplays between urban mobility patterns, socio-economic status and the social network of people from telecommunication or online social network data at the city level. In this work, we follow individuals in the 50 largest metropolitan areas of the United States through their messages sent on the online social networking site, Twitter. Focusing on users with frequent messages containing exact coordinates, we identify their possible home and work location inside cities. Additionally, we construct the social network of users based on mutual followership on the site and analyze how social relationships are formed depending on home and work locations in urban space.

Our results suggest that the structure of individuals' social ties is sensitive to the income levels at their home and work locations. Residents of poor areas who commute to richer parts of a city travel more and tend to have a significantly lower degree in the social network than those who remain to work in the bottom 30% areas. Also, these users have a higher clustering of mutual followers in their ego network and a larger fraction of their friends concentrate geographically close to their home location. We thus discover fundamental patterns in social tie formation using only publicly available geolocated data combined with census information.

Janosov Milán - Sztár DJ-k = sztár mentorok?

Az előadás során betekintést nyújtok a legsikeresebb elektronikus zenei előadók kapcsolatrendszerébe és hálózatos mintáiba egy adat-alapú kutatás keretein belül. Kiemelt figyelmet fordítok a zenei színtér örök klasszikusai, mint mentorok szerepére, és bemutatom, hogyan és milyen mértékben segítik mentori tevékenységükkel a fiatal, feltörekvő zenészek sikerességét. Mindehhez különféle adatbányászati és hálózatelméleti eszközöket használok.

Kárpáti András - Market Basket Analysis Gráf Klaszterezéssel

A fogyasztói viselkedés megértése a kiskereskedelmi adatbányászat egyik legfontosabb feladata. A fogyasztói kosár elemzés (Market Basket Analysis) segítségével fogyasztói profilokat, szokásokat ismerhetünk meg, és ezzel növelhetjük az értékesítés hatékonyságát. Az együtt vásárolt termékek egy hálózatot indukálnak a termékek között, ezt a gráfot szeretnénk megérteni az előadás során. Megismerkedhetünk az Association Rule Mining és a Modularity Clustering technikákkal, melyeket egy ázsiai bolthálózat adatain fogok bemutatni.

The event will be held in Hungarian.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Relational Data Models with the dm Package
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
The first of two meetups in February features Kirill Müller of {DBI} fame.

For the February 11th talk with Thomas Lumley please visit https://www.meetup.com/nyhackr/events/267494537/

Thank you to Rise NY for hosting.

About the Talk:
Kirill will present {dm}, a new package that facilitates working with multiple tables. Three principal use cases can be identified: consuming a data model, building in-memory or local data models without relying on relational databases, and preparing consistent relational data models for consumption by others. Based on these use cases, he outlines the features of this package and discusses future development. The presentation will be interactive with live coding and a script that attendees can run during or after the presentation. The package is available on GitHub at krlmlr.github.io/dm.

About Kirill:
Kirill works on the boundary between data and computer science with more than 20 years of software engineering experience. He enjoys working with and contributing to the R ecosystem since 2012. In 2018 he joined forces with Christoph Sax to found cynkra, a Zurich-based consultancy that helps businesses and government institutions better understand their valuable data and communicate the insights, with a focus on the R ecosystem.

Pizza (https://bit.ly/pizzapoll) begins at 6:30, the talk starts at 7, then after we head to the local bar.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Analysing Multistage Survey Data Using R
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
For the second talk in February we are very excited to have R Core member Thomas Lumley talking about the {survey} package.

For the February 4th talk with Kirill Müller please visit https://www.meetup.com/nyhackr/events/267493644

Thank you to New York Presbyterian for hosting.

About the Talk:
Multistage surveys run by all levels of government and academic research groups are a rich source of data. Traditionally, their analysis involved specialised software (and even specialised hardware); one aim of survey research in recent decades has been to make survey analysis relatively boring, so that it can be done safely by people with domain expertise. I will talk about the R survey package, which just had its 16th birthday. The package allows for exploratory analysis and modelling, and supports research into more efficient estimation in two-phase samples.

About Thomas:
Thomas Lumley is originally from Australia, and was at the University of Washington in Seattle for 15 years. He is now Professor of Biostatistics at the University of Auckland. His research interests include study design in epidemiology, semiparametric theory, computing and graphics, and genomics. Thomas blogs about statistics in the media at statschat.org.nz and about other topics at notstatschat.rbind.io. He is a Fellow of the Royal Society of New Zealand and the American Statistical Association, and a member of R Core, and has taught short courses on R in thirteen time zones.

Pizza (https://bit.ly/pizzapoll) begins at 6:30, the talk starts at 7, then after we head to the local bar.

title: Vienna<-R: Vienna<-R 2020 February
description:
Dear ViennaR members,

We start the new decade with a hot topic in our community: R in production.
Our speakers are Thomas Strehl, Rudolf Pailer, Thomas Weinrich and Mario Annau showing different ways of deploying R models into production.
The Meetup is hosted at IBM Austria (Obere Donaustraße 95) and cool drinks are secured for a lively discussion and networking session afterwards :)

TOPICS

1. Thomas Strehl, Rudolf Pailer, Thomas Weinrich: Aspects of bringing R based machine learning to the enterprise

2. Mario Annau: Deployment of machine learning models using RStudio Connect and the cloud.

DETAILS

1. The enterprise requires Machine Learning to advance from it's 'magic blackbox' nimbus into a well understood and governed asset that evolves from and interacts with enterprise processes. In particular the core assets of machine learning, that is the data, the model creation and verification process, the scoring engine and all interactions with other enterprise applications, need to be subjected to strict version and quality control to ensure traceability and compliance compatibility.

2. Case study showing the creation and deployment of a machine learning model as REST-API and Shiny-app into production using RStudio connect. Alternatively, showing fast API cloud deployments using Qbits: https://www.quantargo.com/qbits

See you there!

Greetings,
ViennaR organizers

description:
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project focused on using tidyverse packages to clean, wrangle, tidy, and plot a new dataset every Tuesday.

We will be using a dataset from the TidyTuedsay Github (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday)
that has been tamed, but does not always adhere to “tidy” data principles. Our goal is to have you take a look at the raw data, and generate either a copy of the original plot or a novel take on the data! You can obviously use whatever techniques you feel are appropriate, but the data will be organized in a way that tidyverse tools will work well!

description:
Welcome to the kick-off of our three-part career series! Over the next three months, we will host events to further develop your skillset and data science network.

Whether or not you're on the job hunt, your resume is an extension of your professional self, so it is important to keep your resume fresh. For our kick-off, our co-organizer Scarlett Winters will lead a tutorial on how to build your resume using pagedown. You will walk away from this tutorial with the skills to prove to employers you know how to code in R well before your interview!

*Prerequisites:
We ask that R-Ladies who are interested in this event please install:
- R:
https://www.r-project.org/

- R Studio:
https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

- Pagedown package, information found here: https://github.com/rstudio/pagedown
https://pagedown.rbind.io/

Additionally, if you have no background with Git or Github, we *strongly* recommend you take a look at modules 4-8 of the free Happy Git with R book (https://happygitwithr.com/github-acct.html) and follow the instructions to get yourself set up ahead of time to reduce pain the day of. title: R-Ladies Philly: 2020 Data Hack: Partner Presentations
description:
(for updates, go to the official hack page here: https://codeforphilly.org/events/datahack2020)

-------------- What is the hack? --------------

Code for Philly, DataPhilly, R Ladies Philly, the Philly Data Jawn, Health Federation of Philadelphia, and Prevention Point are hosting a data science hackathon to answer pertinent questions around the Opioid Crisis in Philadelphia. The goals of this event are to provide health organizations with insights that may normally be unavailable to them and to create analyses that help inform the public about the opioid epidemic in our city.

Hackathon planners have been working with our partners to identify and clean relevant datasets that would be helpful in answering these broader questions:

1) Can we visualize current capacity for Medication Assisted Interventions in Philadelphia to streamline referrals?
2) What have been the effects of granting citizens access to Narcan?
3) How many IV drug users are in Philadelphia?

-------------- How will it work? --------------

The hack is slated to begin on Friday February 7, 2020 with a kickoff event. Partner organizations will present what their group does and why these questions are relevant to them. The next day, participants will have several hours to form their team, consider the questions, and devise a plan to conduct their relevant analysis. Over the next five weeks, these teams will work on their analyses and write their presentations.

-------------- Event Breakdown --------------

Feb 7, 2020 (Friday): Partner presentation night
Feb 8, 2020 (Saturday): First hack day
Feb 11, 2020 (Tuesday): Code for Philly Hack Night
Feb 18, 2020 (Tuesday): Code for Philly Hack Night
Feb 25, 2020 (Tuesday): Code for Philly Hack Night
March 3, 2020 (Tuesday): Code for Philly Hack Night
March 10, 2020 (Tuesday): Code for Philly Hack Night
March 17, 2020 (Tuesday): Presentation night

Participants are not required to attend all events - hack nights are there for teams to have a space and time to regroup. Some hack nights will also have valuable workshops designed to help teams with their analysis and final presentations. In order to give each team a sufficient amount of time on presentation night, there will be no more than 12 teams. Each team is allowed to have as many members as they want.

-------------- How do I sign up? --------------

Given that this is a multi-group effort, we want to avoid possible confusion about which platform to register on. We therefore are keeping Meetup.com registration closed, and ask all participants to register via this Eventbrite link: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/2020-data-hack-data-science-for-a-healthier-community-tickets-86813763303

-------------- Questions? --------------

R-Ladies Philly Slack channel
https://bit.ly/join-rladies-slack-2020 - #projects_2020hack

Code for Philly Slack channel:
https://codeforphilly.org/chat - #data-hack-chat

title: R-Ladies Edinburgh: Scraping and Visualising Twitter Data with Anna Henschel
description:
In this short, hands-on workshop we are going to scrape and visualize our own Twitter data by understanding the basics of text wrangling and by taking advantage of the amazing {tidytext} and {rtweet} packages. By the end of the workshop, you will be able to see if you tweet mostly positive or negative content, and you will be able to plot the most frequent words in a wordcloud. Don't worry if you do not have your own Twitter account - there will be an alternative provided.

Anna Henschel is a third year PhD candidate at the University of Glasgow, where she conducts research in the Social Brain in Action Lab on the ERC-funded Social Robots project. She has a B.Sc. in Psychology from Konstanz University and a M.Sc. cum laude from the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam in Cognitive Neuropsychology. Her feminist activism and work as a STEM ambassador was recently honoured with the YWCA 30 Under 30 Inspirational Women Scotland award. She uses R in her PhD and also just for fun.

You can find her on Twitter (@AnnaHenschel) and check out the workshop Twitter account (@beautiful_hack).

title: R-Ladies Kyiv: Data streaming with Apache Flink
description:
Ververica is the new name of data Artisans, the company founded in 2014 by the original creators of Apache Flink®. with headquartered in Berlin, Germany.

They started Data Artisans (now Ververica) because they saw the need for a large-scale data processing technology that is open source and at the same time properly rooted in long-tested principles and architectures from the database and distributed systems fields.

From the very beginning, they developed Apache Flink® in the open source, and they witnessed and led Flink’s rapid community growth and industry adoption.

The meetup will be about Stateful Stream Processing
The volume of data generated in the world continues to grow steadily. The ability to process these in real time not only opens up new applications but often becomes a necessity to maintain a competitive edge. We will discuss how the horizontally scalable Stateful Stream Processing responds to these new demands and why it can be considered an evolution of the Batch Processing approach. We will also look at the technical complexities involved in building such distributed systems and how they have been resolved in Apache Flink.

Speaker: Alexander Fedulov, Solutions Architect at Ververica

Alexander Fedulov is a Solutions Architect at Ververica (formerly data Artisans). He is advising customers with application design, system integration and performance tuning. Prior to joining Ververica, Alexander worked as a developer and consultant in a variety of companies based in Berlin. He has a Masters Degree (M.Sc.) from the Technical University of Hamburg (TUHH).

Event is totally free to attend, but RSVP is required.
Food and drinks for networking part will be provided:

More information and registration is here:
https://apacheflink.splashthat.com

Follow announcements at FB event: www.facebook.com/events/[masked]

title: R-Ladies London: Tidy up your data science workflow with the tidyverse
description:
Registration to the event is required on Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/tidy-up-your-data-science-workflow-with-the-tidyverse-tickets-91446038563

RLadies London is excited to present Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel!

About the event
The tidyverse is a coherent system of packages for data manipulation, exploration and visualization that share a common design philosophy.
There are core tidyverse packages that you're likely to use in everyday data analyses, and these include:
- ggplot2
- dplyr
- tidyr
- readr
- purrr
- tibble
- stringr
- forecats
We'll be learning a bit about each of these core packages while demonstrating their functionalities!

About the speaker
Mine is a Senior Lecturer in the School of Mathematics at University of Edinburgh and Data Scientist and Professional Educator at RStudio. Mine’s work focuses on innovation in statistics and data science pedagogy, with an emphasis on computing, reproducible research, student-centered learning, and open-source education as well as pedagogical approaches for enhancing retention of women and under-represented minorities in STEM. Mine works on integrating computation into the undergraduate statistics curriculum, using reproducible research methodologies and analysis of real and complex datasets. She is a former R-Ladies RTP and a current R-Ladies Edinburgh organizer.

18:30 Presentation
19:30 Networking

title: R-Ladies Riverside: Tidy Tuesday
description:
Hello RiveRside community ;-)

Come join us for another afternoon of networking and sharing (and pizza!), on Tuesday, February 25th at 5 pm, at Rivera Library 140. This week we will be exploring a recent Tidy Tuesday dataset. Tidy Tuesday is a weekly social data project in R organized by the R4DS Online Learning Community. Come try your hand at wrangling and making a beautiful figure from this dataset to share with us during the meeting, and/or bring your questions. Whether you are new to R or a data scientist, there will be an opportunity for everyone to learn something new. Our lightning talks this week will be presented by UCR's Office of Technology Partnerships (OTP) and they will talk about two exciting OTP programs!

From the Tidy Tuesday website:
"Every week we post a raw dataset, a chart or article related to that dataset, and ask you to explore the data. While the dataset will be 'tamed', it will not always be tidy! As such you might need to apply various R for Data Science techniques to wrangle the data into a true tidy format. The goal of TidyTuesday is to apply your R skills, get feedback, explore other’s work, and connect with the greater #RStats community! As such we encourage everyone of all skills to participate!"

Since a wide range of skill levels are represented by our group :) we've decided to work with the NFL Stadium Attendance from early February as there's more community posted code for inspiration on twitter (check out #tidytuesday):
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2020/2020-02-04/readme.md

Big thanks to UCR Library, UCR GradQuant, andUCR's Office of Technology Partnerships (OTP) supporting us and this event, and special thanks to our sponsor, The Blackstone LaunchPad powered by Techstars at UCR, for providing the pizza!

See you there!!

title: trigeR - Trójmiejska Grupa Entuzjastów R: Deep Learning in R - part III – Convolutional Neural Networks
description:
With the release of the R Keras package (https://keras.rstudio.com/) (by JJ Allaire and Francois Chollet) at the end of 2017 / beginning 2018 the topic of artificial neural networks and especially deep learning in R became red-hot within the R community.

„Deep Learning in R” will be a series of workshops during which you will learn how to use Keras/Tensorflow to solve different deep learning problems using Feedforward, Convolutional, and Recurrent Neural Networks. During workshops we will go through problems like image classification, object localization/detection, image segmentation, dimensionality reduction, time series forecasting, various NLP tasks and more. We will also talk about interpretability of Machine/Deep Learning models using LIME and DALEX packages.

In our third workshop we will talk about Convolutional Neural Networks and transfer learning

After workshop we will have some pizza and drinks :)

Requirements:

Knowledge from first and second meeting: https://www.meetup.com/Trojmiejska-Grupa-Entuzjastow-R/events/267136487/
https://www.meetup.com/Trojmiejska-Grupa-Entuzjastow-R/events/268018583/

During workshops unfortunately there will be no internet connection so participants have to download scripts and datasets before meeting: https://github.com/maju116/trigeR_deep_learning_with_keras_in_R

title: R-Ladies Melbourne: TidyTuesday: collaborative data wrangling and visualisation!
description:
Happy new year everyone!

Join us on Thursday, 27th of February for our first event of 2020 where we will work together on a Tidy Tuesday dataset.

Tidy Tuesday (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday) is a social weekly event where you can practice you wrangling and visualisation skills using real-world data in a safe and supportive forum! Every Tuesday a new dataset is realised.

On the night, We will use the dataset released on Tuesday 25th, divide into groups and work and learn together to produce interesting visualisations. This will be an opportunity to work on real-world data in a collaborative environment as well as to practice sharing your code on GitHub and with the online Twitter community.

**Feel free to download and start working on the dataset prior to the event!**

The data for each week is available on the Tidy Tuesday website: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday.

Looking forward to data wrangling with you,

R-Ladies Melbourne

title: R Glasgow: R Glasgow - February meetup
description:
Hello all, looking forward to seeing you for our February meetup with two fantastic speakers, using R in awesome and creative ways!

Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel

Mine is Senior Lecturer in the School of Mathematics at University of Edinburgh and Data Scientist and Professional Educator at RStudio. Mine’s work focuses on innovation in statistics and data science pedagogy, with an emphasis on computing, reproducible research, student-centered learning, and open-source education as well as pedagogical approaches for enhancing retention of women and under-represented minorities in STEM. Mine works on integrating computation into the undergraduate statistics curriculum, using reproducible research methodologies and analysis of real and complex datasets. You can find her at http://mine-cr.com/

Abstract: From reproducibility to interactivity: In this talk we demo a variety of authoring options in R that you can choose to add interactivity to your static reproducible computational documents using packages like rmarkdown, flexdashboard, shinydashboard, and shiny.

Anna Henschel

Anna is a third year PhD candidate at the University of Glasgow, where she conducts research in the Social Brain in Action Lab on the ERC-funded Social Robots project. She has a B.Sc. in Psychology from Konstanz University and a M.Sc. cum laude from the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam in Cognitive Neuropsychology. Her feminist activism was recently honoured with the YWCA 30 Under 30 Inspirational Women Scotland award. She uses R in her PhD and also just for fun :) You can connect with her on Twitter (@AnnaHenschel), LinkedIn and find her latest publications on her website (www.annahenschel.com).

Abstract: In this short talk, I am reflecting on fun web-scraping pRojects, specifically using the {rtweet} and {SpotifyR} packages. I will provide a walk-through of interacting with the Spotify and Twitter API, share some inspiration for possible ways we can visualize this qualitative data and also some “R-hacks” I like to use. In addition, I am going to talk about my experience of organizing a two day R-workshop (“Hack your data beautiful”) and taking over the We Are R-Ladies Rotating Curator account. I look forward to your questions!

title: R-Ladies Montreal: Leaving academia and diving into data science! Myths, tips and tricks.
description:
In this talk, Erika Braithwaite will discuss some myths about jobs in data science and tricks about how to rebrand yourself if you're leaving academia. Erika will also present some analysis on the 2018 Kaggle Data Scientist Survey to help make talk more data-driven :)

Please come with the most updated version of R and RStudio installed on your laptop. Please see our github page for more details on current and past events, including materials and code! https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_montreal

As usual, snacks and drinks will be provided by our sponsor Upgrade INC.!!

Happy coding :-)

title: R-Ladies Nijmegen: Analyse your data using GAMs in R – All levels welcome!
description:
Have you heard about generalised additive models (GAMs) and would like to know more about how to use them? Come along to this workshop to get an introduction to GAMs: what they are and when and how to use them.

PROGRAMME
Note the different day (Tuesday) and location (Orikami)!

The event will start at 18:30.
Data Scientist Inez Wijnands will start us off with an introduction to the work that Orikami does and then Evelien will tell us all about GAMs!

Inez Wijnands works as a data scientist at Orikami. She studied Artificial Intelligence with a focus on Computational Cognitive Neuroscience at the Radboud University. At Orikami she uses 'AI in healthcare', combining her main interests.

Dr. Evelien Heyselaar is an Assistant Professor in AI and Communication Science at the Radboud University.

Drinks and snacks will be provided by Orikami.

REQUIREMENTS
Don't forget to bring your (fully charged!) laptop with R and R Studio installed.

You can download the materials from: https://github.com/RLadiesNijmegen/GAMMs

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

SPONSORS
We are very grateful to Orikami for sponsoring this event!

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Tidy Tuesday - Come and practice your R skills
description:
Do you want to practice your R-skills? Do you want to improve your abilities to clean, analyse and plot data?

Then this event is what you need! We will use the data from Tidy Tuesday as an excuse to work with R. We will meet to work independently using the same data-set. Each one can choose which analysis to perform or which tools to use (you can already think what you want to practice or learn). We will do this together to have the opportunity to ask others and because coding together is fun!

This activity is for everyone, from beginners to experts. You will set your own goal. We will have a coffee (or what ever you prefer) while working together. This way we can have the opportunity to ask others, to share ideas and code!!

Tidy Tuesday a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. Every week a new data set is uploaded and analysed by the community, then the plots can be shared! Las week data from the fires in Australia was analysed. Have a look at some of the community plots on Tweeter:

https://twitter.com/hashtag/tidytuesday

Bring your own laptop. Hopefully with enough battery.

title: R-Ladies Lima: ¿Quieres conocer cómo se aplica R en varios campos?
description:
¡Primer meetup del 2020!

Empezamos este año con una súper ponente llegada de EEUU, Ph.D. Edith Seier.

• Lo que haremos:
Se mostrará lo útil que es R cuando nos enfrentamos a situaciones nuevas. Se presentará aplicaciones de R sobre la Biología. Se hablará del paquete TraMineR que fue creado para ciencias sociales pero que se adaptó para Biología, así como, aplicaciones de Series de Tiempo.
Finalmente se comentará sobre la vida académica en EEUU.

• ¿Dónde?
Te esperamos en el Auditorio de la Facultad de Ciencias Matemáticas de la Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos.
Dirección: Av. Universitaria /Calle Germán Amézaga 375.

• Requisitos
Ninguno

• Opcional
Llevar laptop si deseas replicar lo que muestra la expositora.

• Información importante
El proceso de inscripción es el siguiente:
1. Regístrate en este meetup (Dale click a 'asistiré' en este evento).
2. Llena tus datos en el siguiente formulario:
https://forms.gle/3nyG6V6kcTeGqgKU8

Debes completar tus datos personales correctamente para poder habilitar tu ingreso.

¡Gracias!

Pregunta frecuente:
P: ¿Los chicos son bienvenidos a las reuniones de R-Ladies Lima?
R: Sí, los chicos son bienvenidos a cualquiera de nuestros eventos. Nuestra misión es empoderar a más mujeres y personas no-binarias para que se involucren en la comunidad R. Por favor, ayúdanos a difundir R-Ladies. Puedes revisar nuestro código de conducta global aquí: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: R-Ladies Madrid: Data Science para Abogados
description:
Empezamos el año con un nuevo evento en colaboración con la Aceleradora de Talento Digital The Bridge, esta vez dirigido al sector jurídico y el primero que se celebra en España.

¿Por qué un evento dirigido al sector jurídico?

En los últimos años hemos visto iniciativas de Inteligencia Artificial aplicadas al sector. En este evento queremos dar una introducción práctica para que aquellos profesionales que estén interesados en saber en qué consiste realmente esta nueva disciplina puedan tenerla de primera mano.

¿Qué aprenderemos?

Instalaremos R Studio

Conceptos básicos del Lenguaje de Programación R

Una introducción al Procesamiento de Lenguaje Natural aplicado a leyes

¡Imprescindible traer el portátil e inscribirse en el enlace de abajo!
https://www.eventbrite.es/e/entradas-data-science-para-abogados-93258519743?aff=rladies

R Ladies

title: R-Ladies Frankfurt: #9: Workflows for reproducible analyses using R
description:

In this first meetup of 2020, we’re going to share experiences about creating effective and reproducible workflows in R and discuss best practices.

Location:
codecentric AG
Kreuznacher Straße 30
60486 Frankfurt am Main

SPECIAL THANKS to codecentric for hosting our event!

What to bring?
(1) laptop with
(2) pre-installed R & RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/)*

If you have any suggestions/questions, please feel free to get in touch: [masked]

Also, follow R-Ladies Frankfurt on twitter: @RLadiesFRA (https://twitter.com/RLadiesFRA) and stay tuned for R and R-Ladies related tweets!

Looking forward to seeing you!
R-Ladies Frankfurt

title: R-Ladies Amsterdam: Putting your R-code into production using Docker containers
description:
Making a quick script for a model or visual in R is something we do everyday. But what if we have some kind of script, model or visual that we would like to use many times a day or make available in a robust way to many users? That's what production is about!
Nowadays, putting code into production, is a complicated story of containers, pipelines, infrastructure, clusters etc. We are going to learn the basics of how to "containerize" your code for production-ready R-coding using Docker-containers. This skill will make you ready to discuss on how to bring your R-code into production within your IT department or in any cloud-environment. We will work in small groups and go step by step so you are ready to rock your code in production!

PROGRAM
---------------
18:00 - 18:30 Welcome & Food
18:30 - 18:45 Intro RLadies and SiaPartners
18:45 - 19:30 Introduction to R in Production
19:30 - 19:45 Break
19:45 - 20:30 Workshop dockerize your R code
20:30 - 21:00 Drinks & Networking

IMPORTANT
For security reasons we need to provide a list of participants. Please use this form to submit your name https://forms.gle/916kPtLAh6qx4n9r9 .

ABOUT INDERDEEP
--------------------------
https://www.linkedin.com/in/inderdeep-singh/
Inderdeep holds a BSc degree in Econometrics from the Free University of Amsterdam and a MSc degree in Econometrics from the Erasmus University of Rotterdam. She has more than 3 years of experience applying data science methods in the insurance industry, lease companies, health care and banking industry. Inderdeep is part of the Data Science Center of Excellence at Sia Partners Amsterdam.

ABOUT SIAPARTNERS
------------------------------
https://sia-partners.com/
Sia Partners is a next-generation consulting firm focused on delivering superior value and tangible results to its clients as they navigate the digital revolution. Our global footprint and our expertise in more than 30 sectors and services allow us to enhance our clients' businesses worldwide. We guide their projects and initiatives in strategy, business transformation, IT & digital strategy, and Data Science. As the pioneer of Consulting 4.0, we develop consulting bots and integrate AI in our solutions.

REQUIREMENTS
----------------------
You should be comfortable to work with R (medium/advanced).

We will use Docker during the meetup. Try if you can install docker on your laptop to get the most out of the event. You need Docker Desktop to work along with the tutorial. https://www.docker.com/products/docker-desktop
We can also help at the beginning to setup docker with you, so pass by at the beginning if you need some help. :)

CODE OF CONDUCT
----------------------------
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

title: R-Ladies Baltimore: R-Ladies Baltimore -- FridayFunday Hackathon!
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

We've decided to change things up a bit and meet for a longer time to work on hacking away on a dataset! We want this to be productive for each of you, so you are encouraged to bring your own dataset / project to make progress on your own analysis. We'll be in the room 9am-4pm and you are welcome to attend all of it or a portion of it. If you are running into problems with your code, we can help debug!

We will aim for lunch to be served.

Details on the location:
615 N. Wolfe St.
Baltimore, MD 21205
Room E9519 (9am-1:30pm)
Room E6519 (1:30-4pm)

FAQ:
Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies. Please also take the time to review our code of conduct before you attend: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

The term "women and gender minorities" is inclusive of individuals who identify as female (trans and cis), trans-men, non-binary, genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, intersex, and all minority genders).

Important to know:
- If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Finally, for more information:

title: R-Ladies Manchester: R-Ladies Manchester Fun with Functions!
description:
R-Ladies first event of 2020

The wonderful Autotrader have agreed to have us back for our first event of 2020 and Kaylea is going to be teaching us all how to "do" functions after giving several impromptu lessons at previous meet-ups!

There will be an "intro to functions" talk to ease you in, with a short hands on session to try it out.

Then we'll kick things up a notch and do some more advanced function uses; think the apply family, pipes and map, again breaking off into groups to try it out.

Then finally we'll open the floor up to your questions and make sure everybody leaves with at least one function that works!

This slightly more intermediate level lesson is still perfect for you if you are new to coding - the sooner you start using functions the sooner you can master them - don't be intimidated - bring your laptop along and we'll help you hit the ground running!

Auto Trader, our venue hosts strive to ensure all events are inclusive, accessible and that all those attending feel as comfortable as possible.
Therefore, whilst signing up, please tell us if you have any of the following requirements:
- Dietary
- Allergies
- Accessibility or specific requirements

title: R-Ladies Lancaster: R Markdown and tips from the RStudio Conference
description:
For our first meeting of 2020 we have two talks lined up:

Rebecca Killick (Lancaster University): R Markdown and why I love it (workshop)

R Markdown is a fantastic tool allowing users to write a huge variety of documents with R code embedded. Rebecca will introduce R Markdown and explain why she loves using it. She'll also teach us how to create a simple R Markdown document. If you want to to participate in the interactive element, please bring a laptop with RStudio and R installed. If you have chance also install the knitr package by running the following command.

install.packages("knitr")

---

Rhian Davies (Jumping Rivers) : What I learnt at RStudio Conference

I'm lucky to be attending the RStudio Conference this year. I'll give a talk summarising some of the new and exciting things I learnt at the conference to share with you all!

---
We will be in Lancaster University Library - Room C135. The session will run from 6pm - 8pm with a short break in the middle. Snacks and soft drinks will be provided.

---

R-Ladies Lancaster is part of a global initiative, R-Ladies Global, designed to improve the gender diversity of R users worldwide and in particular, to improve the participation and experience of women in the R community. As part of the initiative, R-Ladies Lancaster will host a number of talks and workshops about the use of R. It doesn't matter if you never used R or if you are an R expert, R-Ladies Lancaster welcomes anyone with an interest in R.

Questions? E-mail: [masked]

title: R-Ladies San Diego: Hackathon - finding new insights from publicly available datasets
description:
Hey everyone,

Let's get together for another Hackathon! The goal is to use publicly available datasets to extract new insights. It's pretty amazing how much we can learn with some very basic exploratory data analysis in R, from there, the sky is the limit.

We'll start with Elke giving us an example of how she did a really awesome project on small business in San Diego using data from California's Employment Development Department.
If we have time, Juliana will also give an example of how you can use natural language processing with freely available abstracts from scientific papers to learn a bunch of new sciency things!

After that we'll divide into small groups to analyze other datasets or further explore one of the topics above.
You're welcome to use any dataset that interests you. Try google dataset search to see if anything out there sparks your curiosity. Kaggle also has loads of cool datasets available.

We'll end the evening sharing what the different groups have done.

Hope to see you all soon!

You can find links to the resources mentioned above below:
California EDD Labor Market Information Resources and Data: https://www.labormarketinfo.edd.ca.gov/LMID/Size_of_Business_Data.html
Biomedical natural language processing datasets and models: http://bio.nlplab.org/
Google's dataset search: https://datasetsearch.research.google.com/
Kaggle datasets: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets

title: R-Ladies Johannesburg: Feb meetup: ggWhat to ggplot - a guide to creating powerful visualisations
description:
Data visualisation is one of the most important tools for any person working with data, but often finds itself as an afterthought in both theory and practice of data science. A well designed visual reveals the hidden story behind the data and has the potential to bring about change.

This talk will not only take you through the fundamentals of using the ggplot package to generate visualisations, but also the core principals and best practices needed to make it powerful.

The session is hands-on, so if you want to follow along please install the tidyverse.

Please join us, and the lovely Gemma Dawson as she takes us through this important topic!

Packages:
install.packages("tidyverse")

Please also install the packages below:

library(ggplot2movies) # install.packages("ggplot2movies")
library(cowplot) # install.packages("cowplot")
library(ggrepel) # install.packages("ggrepel")
library(gghighlight) # install.packages("gghighlight")
library(ggedit) # install.packages("ggedit")

title: EdinbR: The Edinburgh R Usergroup: Working with Tree Structures and Manipulating and visualizing weather data
description:
Hi everyone,

Our Febrary session will be on 19th, so join us from 6.00pm in Old College, Usha Kasera Lecture Theatre (https://www.ed.ac.uk/timetabling-examinations/timetabling/room-bookings/bookable-rooms3/room/0001_01_1.264) (map: https://www.openstreetmap.org/relation/33710). As usual, the meeting will be open for all to attend, and newcomers / beginners are very welcome. After the talks we'll be heading off to a pub nearby, so do come along!

Our speakers are Greg Sutcliffe and Juliette Maire. Greg is a community data scientist at Ansible and Red Hat. Juliette is a PhD student at Scotland's Rural College.

---

## Roots'n'All - Working with Tree Structures in R
### Greg Sutcliffe (https://twitter.com/Gwmngilfen)

Tree structures are common - from the files on your computer to the hierarchy of your organisation, there's a wealth of data contained both within the objects of the tree *and* the links between them. There are many questions one might wish to ask of such a tree, concerning the depth/breadth of the whole tree, or calculations across parts of it.

Working with the trees is made possible in R via the `data.tree` library, and visualization can be done with `ggraph` extensions to ggplot2. In this talk, we'll cover how to create a tree object (say, from a data frame), how to calculate some properties on each part of the tree, and how to visualize the result.

---

## Manipulating and visualizing weather data
### Juliette Maire (https://www.sruc.ac.uk/jmaire)

Large-scale weather dataset (historical or predictions) is usually a "big" multidimensional dataset that includes space, time components and various variables such as rain, temperature, wind speed. Weather dataset is often saved as NetCDF file. This talk is a quick introduction to how to simply handle such files, extract or manipulate data from it, and visualize the results in R.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Survey analysis: beyond the subscripts
description:
Abstract:
Analysing complex sampling -- cluster samples, unequal probabilities, stratification -- used to be a separate and somewhat isolated area of statistics. Some books on the topic might have given the impression it was mostly about the care and feeding of subscripts. In fact, well-conducted complex sampling gives data with important differences from other data sources, but ones whose impact on the analysis is limited. Modern survey analysis software is aimed at reducing the differences to a minimum, so analysts and domain experts can analyse complex surveys correctly in most straightforward cases. I will talk about how you can use the R survey package to do most of the analyses you already do, but with data from complex surveys. ​

Bio:
Thomas Lumley is originally from Australia, but worked in Seattle, at the University of Washington, for 12 years. He is currently Professor of Biostatistics at the University of Auckland, where he teaches statistics and data science. Thomas is the developer of the R survey package, and a member of R Core. He has taught workshops on R in 13 time zones.

Another purpose of those meetings is to provide space for the professional networking and knowledge exchange for practitioners and students from the areas of statistical machine learning, programming, optimization and data science.

Why R? have already managed to co-organize 30 R meetups around Central-Eastern Europe, among others in Warsaw, Prague, Amsterdam, Copenhagen or Wroclaw. Such meetings are a great opportunity to understand the needs and areas of interest of R users around the Europe.
